markupsafe

Classes

Markup

A string that is ready to be safely inserted into an HTML or XML

EscapeFormatter

Package Contents

markupsafe.escape(s: Any, /) → Markup[source]

Replace the characters &, <, >, ', and " in the string with HTML-safe sequences. Use this if you need to display text that might contain such characters in HTML.

If the object has an __html__ method, it is called and the return value is assumed to already be safe for HTML.

Parameters:

s – An object to be converted to a string and escaped.

Returns:

A Markup string with the escaped text.

markupsafe.escape_silent(s: Any | None, /) → Markup[source]

Like escape() but treats None as the empty string. Useful with optional values, as otherwise you get the string 'None' when the value is None.

>>> escape(None)
Markup('None')
>>> escape_silent(None)
Markup('')
markupsafe.soft_str(s: Any, /) → str[source]

Convert an object to a string if it isn’t already. This preserves a Markup string rather than converting it back to a basic string, so it will still be marked as safe and won’t be escaped again.

>>> value = escape("<User 1>")
>>> value
Markup('&lt;User 1&gt;')
>>> escape(str(value))
Markup('&amp;lt;User 1&amp;gt;')
>>> escape(soft_str(value))
Markup('&lt;User 1&gt;')
class markupsafe.Markup[source]

Bases: str

A string that is ready to be safely inserted into an HTML or XML document, either because it was escaped or because it was marked safe.

Passing an object to the constructor converts it to text and wraps it to mark it safe without escaping. To escape the text, use the escape() class method instead.

>>> Markup("Hello, <em>World</em>!")
Markup('Hello, <em>World</em>!')
>>> Markup(42)
Markup('42')
>>> Markup.escape("Hello, <em>World</em>!")
Markup('Hello &lt;em&gt;World&lt;/em&gt;!')

This implements the __html__() interface that some frameworks use. Passing an object that implements __html__() will wrap the output of that method, marking it safe.

>>> class Foo:
...     def __html__(self):
...         return '<a href="/foo">foo</a>'
...
>>> Markup(Foo())
Markup('<a href="/foo">foo</a>')

This is a subclass of str. It has the same methods, but escapes their arguments and returns a Markup instance.

>>> Markup("<em>%s</em>") % ("foo & bar",)
Markup('<em>foo &amp; bar</em>')
>>> Markup("<em>Hello</em> ") + "<foo>"
Markup('<em>Hello</em> &lt;foo&gt;')
join(iterable: collections.abc.Iterable[str | _HasHTML], /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Concatenate any number of strings.

The string whose method is called is inserted in between each given string. The result is returned as a new string.

Example: ‘.’.join([‘ab’, ‘pq’, ‘rs’]) -> ‘ab.pq.rs’

split(/, sep: SupportsIndex = None, maxsplit=-1) → list[typing_extensions.Self][source]

Return a list of the substrings in the string, using sep as the separator string.

sep

The separator used to split the string.

When set to None (the default value), will split on any whitespace character (including n r t f and spaces) and will discard empty strings from the result.

maxsplit

Maximum number of splits. -1 (the default value) means no limit.

Splitting starts at the front of the string and works to the end.

Note, str.split() is mainly useful for data that has been intentionally delimited. With natural text that includes punctuation, consider using the regular expression module.

rsplit(/, sep: SupportsIndex = None, maxsplit=-1) → list[typing_extensions.Self][source]

Return a list of the substrings in the string, using sep as the separator string.

sep

The separator used to split the string.

When set to None (the default value), will split on any whitespace character (including n r t f and spaces) and will discard empty strings from the result.

maxsplit

Maximum number of splits. -1 (the default value) means no limit.

Splitting starts at the end of the string and works to the front.

splitlines(/, keepends=False) → list[typing_extensions.Self][source]

Return a list of the lines in the string, breaking at line boundaries.

Line breaks are not included in the resulting list unless keepends is given and true.

unescape(/) → str[source]

Convert escaped markup back into a text string. This replaces HTML entities with the characters they represent.

>>> Markup("Main &raquo; <em>About</em>").unescape()
'Main » <em>About</em>'
striptags(/) → str[source]

unescape() the markup, remove tags, and normalize whitespace to single spaces.

>>> Markup("Main &raquo;        <em>About</em>").striptags()
'Main » About'
classmethod escape(s: Any, /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Escape a string. Calls escape() and ensures that for subclasses the correct type is returned.

capitalize(/) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a capitalized version of the string.

More specifically, make the first character have upper case and the rest lower case.

title(/) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a version of the string where each word is titlecased.

More specifically, words start with uppercased characters and all remaining cased characters have lower case.

lower(/) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a copy of the string converted to lowercase.

upper(/) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a copy of the string converted to uppercase.

replace(old: str, new: str, count: SupportsIndex = -1, /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a copy with all occurrences of substring old replaced by new.

count

Maximum number of occurrences to replace. -1 (the default value) means replace all occurrences.

If the optional argument count is given, only the first count occurrences are replaced.

ljust(width: SupportsIndex, fillchar: str = ' ', /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a left-justified string of length width.

Padding is done using the specified fill character (default is a space).

rjust(width: SupportsIndex, fillchar: str = ' ', /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a right-justified string of length width.

Padding is done using the specified fill character (default is a space).

lstrip(chars: str | None = None, /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a copy of the string with leading whitespace removed.

If chars is given and not None, remove characters in chars instead.

rstrip(chars: str | None = None, /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a copy of the string with trailing whitespace removed.

If chars is given and not None, remove characters in chars instead.

center(width: SupportsIndex, fillchar: str = ' ', /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a centered string of length width.

Padding is done using the specified fill character (default is a space).

strip(chars: str | None = None, /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a copy of the string with leading and trailing whitespace removed.

If chars is given and not None, remove characters in chars instead.

translate(table: collections.abc.Mapping[int, str | int | None], /) → str[source]

Replace each character in the string using the given translation table.

table

Translation table, which must be a mapping of Unicode ordinals to Unicode ordinals, strings, or None.

The table must implement lookup/indexing via __getitem__, for instance a dictionary or list. If this operation raises LookupError, the character is left untouched. Characters mapped to None are deleted.

expandtabs(/, tabsize=8) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a copy where all tab characters are expanded using spaces.

If tabsize is not given, a tab size of 8 characters is assumed.

swapcase(/) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Convert uppercase characters to lowercase and lowercase characters to uppercase.

zfill(width: SupportsIndex, /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Pad a numeric string with zeros on the left, to fill a field of the given width.

The string is never truncated.

casefold(/) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a version of the string suitable for caseless comparisons.

removeprefix(prefix: str, /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a str with the given prefix string removed if present.

If the string starts with the prefix string, return string[len(prefix):]. Otherwise, return a copy of the original string.

removesuffix(suffix: str) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

Return a str with the given suffix string removed if present.

If the string ends with the suffix string and that suffix is not empty, return string[:-len(suffix)]. Otherwise, return a copy of the original string.

partition(sep: str, /) → tuple[typing_extensions.Self, typing_extensions.Self, typing_extensions.Self][source]

Partition the string into three parts using the given separator.

This will search for the separator in the string. If the separator is found, returns a 3-tuple containing the part before the separator, the separator itself, and the part after it.

If the separator is not found, returns a 3-tuple containing the original string and two empty strings.

rpartition(sep: str, /) → tuple[typing_extensions.Self, typing_extensions.Self, typing_extensions.Self][source]

Partition the string into three parts using the given separator.

This will search for the separator in the string, starting at the end. If the separator is found, returns a 3-tuple containing the part before the separator, the separator itself, and the part after it.

If the separator is not found, returns a 3-tuple containing two empty strings and the original string.

format(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

S.format(*args, **kwargs) -> str

Return a formatted version of S, using substitutions from args and kwargs. The substitutions are identified by braces (‘{’ and ‘}’).

format_map(mapping: collections.abc.Mapping[str, Any], /) → typing_extensions.Self[source]

S.format_map(mapping) -> str

Return a formatted version of S, using substitutions from mapping. The substitutions are identified by braces (‘{’ and ‘}’).
